review.title: Lifted Variable Elimination for Probabilistic Logic Programming
review.abstract: Lifted inference has been proposed for various probabilistic logical frameworks in order to compute the probability of queries in a time that is polynomial in the size of the domains of the logical variables rather than exponential. Even if various authors have underlined its importance for probabilistic logic programming (PLP), lifted inference has been applied up to now only to relational languages outside of logic programming. In this paper we adapt Generalized Counting First Order Variable Elimination (GC-FOVE) to the problem of computing the probability of queries to probabilistic logic programs under the distribution semantics. In particular, we extend the Prolog Factor Language (PFL) to include two new types of factors that are needed for representing ProbLog programs. These factors take into account the existing causal independence relationships among some of the random variables and are managed by the extension to variable elimination proposed by Zhang and Poole for dealing with convergent variables and heterogeneous factors. Two new operators are added to GC-FOVE for treating heterogeneous factors. The resulting algorithm, called LP^2 for Lifted Probabilistic Logic Programming, has been implemented by modifying the PFL implementation of GC-FOVE and tested on three benchmarks for lifted inference. The comparison with PITA and ProbLog2 shows the potential of the approach. Note: To appear in Theory and Practice of Logic Programming (TPLP).

sections.heading: 2.2 The Prolog Factor Language
sections.text: Most graphical models provide a concise representation of a common distribution by encoding it as a set of factors. The probability of a set of variables X taking the value x can be expressed as a product of n factors if: P (X = x) = i = 1,..., n φi (xi) Zwhere xi is a subvector of x that depends on the i-th factor and Z is a normalization constant (i.e. Z = x = i = 1,..., n φi (xi))). Bayean networks are an example where there is a factor for each variable that is a function of the variable Xi and its parents Xj.. Xk, so that these dimensions (Xi, Xj. Xk) = P (Xi | Xj.) and Z = 1. As progress has been made in managing large networks, it has become clear that the same factor repeatedly appears in the network.

sections.heading: 2.3 Variable Elimination and Causal Independence
sections.text: It is very often the case that we want to find out what the probability distribution is of a series of random variables X, because we know the values or have evidence y, on a series of variables Y, where X is often a single variable X. Variable elimination (ve) (Zhang and Poole 1996) is an algorithm for calculating this trailing probability in factored probability distributions. The key idea is then to eliminate the random variables one by one from a series of factors until only the query variable X is left. To do this, one eliminates a variable V by first multiplying all factors that include V into a single factor; V can then be calculated by summing up the newly constructed factor.Formally, suppose 1 (X1. Xi, Y1. Yy.) and 2 (Y1. Yj. Yy, Zk.) are factors (Z1.).

sections.heading: 2.4 GC-FOVE
sections.text: It represents the adaptation of GC-FOVE to the PFL language by repeatedly applying operators that raise the counterparts of the operators. Models are in the form of parameters that are essentially the same as in PFL. A parameterized random variable (PRV) V of the form A | C, where A = F,. Xn is a restriction to logical variables (PRV).

sections.heading: 3 Translating ProbLog into PFL
sections.text: To translate ProbLog into PFL, let's assume the conversion of a ProbLog factor = 1 person-identity factor = 1 person-identity factor into a Bayesian network with noisy OR nodes. Here, we adjust the conversion for Logic Programs with Annotated Disjunctions, which is in (Vennekens et al. 2004; Meert et al. 2008) in the case of ProbLog. The first step is to generate the grounding of the ProbLog program (CPT). For each atom A in the Herbrand base of the program, the Bayesian network contains a Boolean random variable with the same name. Each probable fact is p:: A is represented by a parentless node with the conditional probability table (CPT).

sections.heading: 4 Heterogeneous Lifted Multiplication and Summation
sections.text: GC-FOVE must be modified to take heterogeneous factors and convergent variables into account; the ve algorithm must be replaced by ve1, i.e. two lists of factors must be maintained, one with homogeneous and the other with heterogeneous factors; when adding a variable, the homogeneous factors must first be combined with homogeneous multiplications ({2}); then the heterogeneous factors must be combined with heterogeneous multiplications; and finally, the two results must be combined to produce a definitive factor from which the random variable is eliminated; Lifted heterogeneous multiplication is defined as operator 1, with the two factors sharing convergent random variables; we assume that we have familiarity with set and relative algebra (e.g., combine. /), while some useful definitions in applications such as PRVs must be reported that the corresponding parameters must be taken into account.

sections.heading: 5 Experiments
sections.text: To evaluate the performance of the LP2 algorithm, we compare it with PITA and ProbLog2 in two problems: workshop attributes (Milch et al. 2008) and Example 7 in (Poole 2008), which we call plates. Code of all problems can be found in Appendix A. In addition, we have a scalability test on a third problem: competing workshops (Milch et al. 2008). All tests were performed on a machine with an Intel dual core E6550 2.33GHz processor and 4GB of memory. The workshop attributes problem differs from Example 1 because the first set for the series is missing and the second set contains a probable atom in its body. The competing workshop problems differ from workshop attributes because it differs from workshop attributes, a set of competing workshops W, each with a binary hot (W) variable indicating whether it is focused on popular research areas.

sections.heading: 6 Conclusions
sections.text: We have proven that with the introduction of the two new heterogeneous operators, we can calculate the probability of queries following the distribution semantics very efficiently. Experimental evidence shows that LP2 can achieve several orders of magnitude of improvement, both in terms of runtime and in the number of facts that can be managed effectively. In the future, we plan to compare our approach with that of (Kisynski and Poole 2009b; Takikawa and D'Ambrosio 1999; Deez and Gala'n 2003) in order to deal with noise or factors and compare it with the weighted model count of first order (Van den Broeck et al. 2014).

sections.heading: Appendix B Definitions
sections.text: Definition 1 (Counting formula) A Counting formula is a syntactical construct of the form # Xi-C [F (X)], where Xi-X is called a counted logvar. A Counting formula is a counting formula in which all arguments of the atom F (X), except the counted logvar, are constants. It defines a counting of X (CRV) as the following result. Definition 2 (Counting randvar) A Counting randvar (PCRV) is a pair (# Xi [F (X)]], C). For each counting of X\ Xi, a separate counting randvar (CRV) is generated. The value of this CRV is a histogram, and it depends deterministically on the values of F (X). Given an evaluation for F (X), it counts how many different values of the Xi range (F).

In fact, the lifted ve algorithm of (Gomes and Costa 2012) represents the adaptation of GC-FOVE to the PFL constraints.

An experimental comparison between LP and ProbLog2 (Fierens et al. 2014) and PITA (Riguzzi and Swift 2011) shows that inference time increases linearly with the number of individuals of the program domain for LP, rather than exponentially as with ProbLog2 and PITA.

As progress has been made on managing large networks, it has become clear that often the same factor appears repeatedly in the network, thus suggesting the use of templates generalizing individual factors, or parametric factors (Kisynski and Poole 2009a).
The Prolog Factor Language (PFL) (Gomes and Costa 2012) extends Prolog to support probabilistic reasoning with parametric factors or parfactors.

Causal independence (Zhang and Poole 1996) goes one step further and looks at independence conditioned on values of the random variables.

The lifted ve algorithm of (Gomes and Costa 2012) represents the adaptation of GC-FOVE to the PFL language.

First-order Variable Elimination (FOVE) (Poole 2003; de Salvo Braz et al. 2005) computes the marginal probability distribution for query random variables (randvars) by repeatedly applying operators that are lifted counterparts of ve’s operators.
GC-FOVE further extends PRVs with counting formulas, introduced in C-FOVE (Milch et al. 2008).

metadata.abstractText: Lifted inference has been proposed for various probabilistic logical frameworks in order to compute the probability of queries in a time that depends on the size of the domains of the random variables rather than the number of instances. Even if various authors have underlined its importance for probabilistic logic programming (PLP), lifted inference has been applied up to now only to relational languages outside of logic programming. In this paper we adapt Generalized Counting First Order Variable Elimination (GC-FOVE) to the problem of computing the probability of queries to probabilistic logic programs under the distribution semantics. In particular, we extend the Prolog Factor Language (PFL) to include two new types of factors that are needed for representing ProbLog programs. These factors take into account the existing causal independence relationships among random variables and are managed by the extension to variable elimination proposed by Zhang and Poole for dealing with convergent variables and heterogeneous factors. Two new operators are added to GC-FOVE for treating heterogeneous factors. The resulting algorithm, called LP for Lifted Probabilistic Logic Programming, has been implemented by modifying the PFL implementation of GC-FOVE and tested on three benchmarks for lifted inference. A comparison with PITA and ProbLog2 shows the potential of the approach.
